case_name: Railway Company v. Upper Doab Sugar Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 347 of 1955 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 347 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 20, 1955 of Railway Rates Tribunal, Madras in Complaint No. 2 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 20, 1955, of the Railway Rates Tribunal, Madras, in Complaint No. 2 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 9, 1960 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. February 9. Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Upper Doab Sugar Mills Ltd. manufactures sugar at Mills situated at Shamli.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, the Upper Doab Sugar Mills Ltd., manufactures sugar in its Mills situated at Shamli.

facts.text: Sugarcane brought by Company from different places in neighbourhood to Shamli via Railway.

anchor.surface_text: The sugarcane needed as its raw material has to be brought by the Company from different places in the neighbourhood.

facts.text: Railway Company carries sugarcane in trucks from several stations to Shamli.

anchor.surface_text: The Railway Company carries the sugarcane in trucks from several stations on its line, to Shamli.

facts.text: Mills had siding agreement with Railway Company since starting functioning.

anchor.surface_text: As the Mills premises are situated a short distance away from the station platform the Mills had at the very time when it started functioning, a siding agreement with the Railway Company

facts.text: Nearest point of Mills siding from Shamli station platform is 100 to 150 ft away.

anchor.surface_text: The nearest point of the Mills siding from the station platform at Shamli is about 100 to 150 ft. away.

facts.text: Railway locomotives bring sugarcane trucks to point A, then Mills arranges further.

anchor.surface_text: Tile Rly. loco-motives bring the sugarcane trucks to this point-pt. A in the Plan-after which the Mills makes its own arrangement for taking them inside the sidings.

facts.text: Charges for sugarcane up to September 30, 1953: From Ailum Rs. 3-8-0, etc.

anchor.surface_text: the charges payable in respect of sugarcane carried in the Railway Companys trucks and brought by the Railway Companys locomotives up to the point A stood on September 30, 1953, at the following figures- Rs. Ans. ps. From Ailum 3 8 - Kandhla 3 8 -

facts.text: Surcharge of annas 2 per rupee added to charges.

anchor.surface_text: In each case a surcharge of annas 2 per rupee was added.

facts.text: Central Government order dated February 20, 1950 under s.32 fixing terminal charges at 6 pies per maund at each end where owners do loading/unloading.

anchor.surface_text: Before this, however, on February 20, 1950, the Central Govt., had made an order under s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act... Six pies per maund at each end, where the owners of the goods are required to do loading and unloading

facts.text: Railway Company did not levy terminal charges per Govt order until September 1953.

anchor.surface_text: In spite of this however the Railway Company did number levy any terminal charges in accordance with this rate up to September, 1953

facts.text: Railway issued Local Rate Advice on August 1, 1953 effective 1-10-53 introducing station to station rates plus terminal Rs. 9.6 etc.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1953 the Railway Company issued a Local Rate Advice the relevant portion of which was in these terms - With effect from I- 10-53 the following station to station rates... Sugarcane Ailum Shamli Rs. 2.6 plus terminal Rs. 9.6

facts.text: Total charges increased from October 1953, e.g., Ailum from Rs.3-8 to Rs.11-12.

anchor.surface_text: The companysequence of this was that with effect from October 1953 the total charges payable by the Mills rose companysiderably. From Rs. 3-8 formerly payable in respect of sugarcane carried from Ailum... became Rs. 11-12

facts.text: Mills filed complaint under s.41(1)(i) to Railway Rates Tribunal against increase.

anchor.surface_text: It was for relief against this increase that the Mills made a companyplaint under s. 41 1   i  of the Indian Railways Act to the Railway Rates Tribunal.

facts.text: Other relief prayers for molasses etc. withdrawn before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Relief in respect of certain other matters like rates on molasses... was also asked for but later all these prayers having been withdrawn at the hearing before the Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal dealt only with sugarcane charges increase.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal bad to deal only with the Mills companyplaint as regards this increase in charges in respect of sugarcane.

facts.text: Railway contended no complaint under s.41 as standardized terminal charges applied.

anchor.surface_text: The main companytention raised on behalf of the Railway Company was that as in increasing the charges the Administration had merely applied standardized terminal charges

facts.text: Railway contended considerable services rendered apart from carriage justifying terminals.

anchor.surface_text: The Railway Company also further companytended in this companynection that companysiderable services, apart from the carriage of the goods, were rendered by the Company at each end

facts.text: Tribunal majority held jurisdiction exists, services only at loading station, reduced terminal to Rs.4.11 annas.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal by a majority held that this was number a case of application of a standardized terminal charge... They ordered a reduction of terminal charge from Rs. 9.6 to Rs. 4.11.

facts.text: Tribunal President minority: no jurisdiction, services at both ends.

anchor.surface_text: The President of the Tribunal Mr. Lokur, forming the minority, was of opinion that the Tribunal had numberjurisdiction... terminal services were rendered by the respondent Railways both at the loading station and also after the carriage

facts.text: Supreme Court held Tribunal wrong, it is standardized terminal charge, no jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Tribunal  by which we mean the majority of the Tribunal  was wrong in thinking that this was number a case of standardized terminal charges.

facts.text: Average 200 mds. carried per 4 wheeler truck, undisputed.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear to be disputed that on an average 200 mds. are carried in each 4 wheeler truck.

facts.text: Exhibit A-6 shows bills Feb 1953 to Feb 10, 1953 with 200 mds per truck on capacity basis.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit A-6 shows a number of bills for charges for the period February, 1953 to February 10, 1953, for sugarcane carried... In each case we find 200 mds. mentioned as the weight.

facts.text: Carriage charge per truck based on 150 mds., common ground.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears to be companymon ground that this charge is actually calculated on the basis of 15O mds. per truck.

facts.text: Siding agreement Clause 13: Freight charged up to and from Shamli station.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 Freight for all clauses of goods will be charged up to and from Shamli station.

facts.text: Siding agreement provides additional charges for placing/removing wagons from lines A and B.

anchor.surface_text: In addition to such freight, the Railway Administration will make the following charges... 1  per 4-wheeler wagon 0-3-4

facts.text: Court finds carriage charged up to station platform only, haulage to point A is terminal service.

anchor.surface_text: On a proper reading of these clauses we think it reasonable to hold that carriage up to the station platform only was being charged for. The haulage of, the trucks from the station platform to point A was thus necessarily a service

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Tribunal order, rejects complaint under s.41.

anchor.surface_text: The order made by the Tribunal is therefore set aside. The application made under s. 41 in respect of this levy of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck in addition to the carriage is rejected.

issues.text: When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, has the Railway Rates Tribunal jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased?

anchor.surface_text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, has the Railway Rates Tribunal jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased ? That is the question raised in this appeal.

issues.text: Whether the charge of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck is an application of the standardized terminal charges of 6 pies per maund at each end fixed by the Central Government under s.32?

anchor.surface_text: on February 20, 1950, the Central Govt., had made an order under s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, the relevant portion of which is in these words- In pursuance of section 32 of the Indian Rlys. Act, 1890  IX of 1890  the Central Government is pleased to fix the following rates of terminals...

issues.text: Whether terminal charges under s.3(14) can be levied only if services in addition to carriage are rendered?

anchor.surface_text: definition of the terminals in s. 3 14  no charges are payable unless certain services... Acceptance of that view will undoubtedly justify a conclusion that in fixing terminals the Central Government only authorized the charges to be levied, on certain services in addition to carriage having been rendered.

issues.text: Up to what point is carriage charged under the siding agreement, and is haulage from station platform to point A a terminal service?
issues.answer: carriage up to station platform; haulage to point A is terminal service

issues.text: What is the interpretation of the phrase 'in respect of' in the definition of 'terminals' in s.3(14): charges for provision/maintenance or only for use?
issues.answer: charges for provision and maintenance irrespective of use

anchor.surface_text: Terminals includes charges in respect of stations, sidings... and of any service rendered thereat... charges for the mere provision and maintenance... irrespective of whether any use was made thereof.

arguments.claim: No absurdity in charging for provision irrespective of use; avoids disputes

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that a limited interpretation... where the literal interpretation... absurd... no such reason... interminable disputes... unhelpful to... public.

arguments.claim: Haulage beyond normal point to siding is terminal service, adapting English precedent

anchor.surface_text: Applying the reasoning underlying this decision to Indian conditions we think it proper to hold that haulage beyond a point where the trucks would be taken... would be a terminal service

holdings.text: When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, the Railway Rates Tribunal has no jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased.

anchor.surface_text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, has the Railway Rates Tribunal jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased ? That is the question raised in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.41 excludes complaints on standardized terminal charges fixed under s.32; levy of Rs.9.6 is such application.

holdings.text: The charge of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck is an application of the standardized terminal charges of 6 pies per maund at each end fixed by the Central Government under s.32.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Tribunal  by which we mean the majority of the Tribunal  was wrong in thinking that this was not a case of standardized terminal charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rs.9.6 equivalent to 6 pies/maund on 150 mds. basis (common ground for carriage calculation); lump sum valid without actual weighment.

holdings.text: Terminal charges under s.3(14) can be levied irrespective of whether services in addition to carriage are rendered.

anchor.surface_text: Terminals includes charges in respect of stations, sidings, wharves, depots, warehouses, cranes and other similar matters, and of any service rendered thereat... charges for the mere provision and maintenance... irrespective of whether any use was made thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition covers two classes: provision/maintenance of facilities AND services; no absurdity in charging for provision to avoid disputes.

holdings.text: Under the siding agreement, freight/carriage is charged up to and from Shamli station platform; haulage from station platform to point A is a terminal service.

anchor.surface_text: On a proper reading of these clauses we think it reasonable to hold that carriage up to the station platform only was being charged for. The haulage of, the trucks from the station platform to point A was thus necessarily a service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.13 explicitly: freight to/from Shamli station; cl.15 additional shunting charges separate.

holdings.text: The phrase 'in respect of' in s.3(14) definition of 'terminals' means charges for the provision and maintenance of stations, sidings etc., irrespective of actual use or services rendered thereat.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Generality of language not cut down (no absurdity); practical necessity to avoid per-use disputes; reproduces English Act post-judgment affirming provision charges.

holdings.text: The Tribunal's order reducing terminal charges is set aside; the complaint under s.41 is rejected as Tribunal lacked jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The order made by the Tribunal is therefore set aside. The application made under s. 41 in respect of this levy of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck in addition to the carriage is rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Levy is standardized terminals under s.32; s.41 excludes jurisdiction over reasonableness.

holdings.text: Haulage beyond station platform to private siding (point A) constitutes a terminal service, even adapting English precedent on conveyance vs. carrier duties.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the reasoning underlying this decision to Indian conditions we think it proper to hold that haulage beyond a point where the trucks would be taken for persons other than the owners of a siding would be a terminal service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to English cases distinguishing conveyance end; but not rested on as primary ground (definition covers provision anyway).

precedents.citation: Foster v G. E. Railway Co. 1 1920 K.B. 574

anchor.surface_text: In Foster v G. E. Railway Co.  1 , the Court had to consider certain sections of the Great Eastern Railway Company  Rates and Charges  Order Confirmation Act, 1891. Section 2 thereof provided that the maximum rate for companyveyance is the maximum rate which the companypany may charge for the companyveyance of merchandise by merchandise train and, subject to the exceptions and provisions specified in the schedule includes the provisions of locomotive power and trucks by the companypany, and every other expense incidental to such companyveyance number hereinafter provided for. Section 3 provides that the maximum station terminal is the maximum charge which the companypany may make to a trader for the use of the accommodation  exclusive of companyl  provided and for the duties undertaken by the companypany for which numberother provision is made in the schedule, at the terminal station for or in dealing with merchandise, as carriers thereof, before or after companyveyance. Section 5 provides that the companypany may charge for the services for the following, or any of them, when rendered to a trader at his request or for his companyvenience, a reasonable sum, by way of addition to the tonnage rate, and services rendered by the Company, at or in companynection with sidings number belonging to the Company. It was in companynection with this scheme of the law that the Court had to consider where companyveyance should be held to end. It was held that companyveyance for the purpose of rates might or might number companyncide with the companytractual companyveyance but that it companyld number be said as matter of law that it did. The point at which it ended would prima facie be the point at which the goods train detached and deposited the Trucks, but if they were so detached and deposited for the companyvenience of the railway companypany at a point short of that to which as companyveyers they would be bound to take them for the purposes of delivery to a

precedents.case_name: Foster v Great Eastern Railway Co
precedents.cited_proposition: conveyance for the purpose of rates might or might not coincide with contractual conveyance; prima facie ends where goods train detaches trucks; if detached short for railway convenience no extra charge for haulage between points
precedents.cited_holding: haulage between detachment point (for railway convenience) and delivery point cannot be charged in addition to conveyance charge

precedents.citation: Hall Co. v. London, Brighton and South Coast Rly., Co. 2 1885 15 K.B. 505 Halls Case 2

anchor.surface_text: an English Court had held in Hall Co. v. London, Brighton and South Coast Rly., Co.  2 , that for the purposes of interpretation of section 51 of the London, Brighton, and South Coast Rly. Act, 1863 which did number include such a definition of terminal charges, the words any service incidental to the duty or business of a carrier, does companyprise providing such station accommodation and such sidings, and such weighing, checking and labelling as is incidental to the duty which they undertake, of companylecting and dealing with the goods as carriers. It is reasonable to think that the English Parliament in defining terminal charges in the Railway and Canals Act, 1889 intended to give effect to this view that provision of station accommodation and sidings entitled the Railway Administration to levy terminal charges. When the. Indian Legislature adopted the same definition in its own Act it is proper to think that it also was aware of the view taken in Halls Case  2 . This companysideration fortifies the companyclusion which we have already reached on an examination of the scheme of our own Act, apart from authorities, that the words in respect of used in s. 3 14  in the definition of

precedents.case_name: Hall & Co v London, Brighton and South Coast Railway Co
precedents.cited_proposition: any service incidental to the duty or business of a carrier comprises providing station accommodation, sidings, weighing, checking, labelling incidental to collecting and dealing with goods as carriers
precedents.cited_holding: provision of station accommodation and sidings constitutes service incidental to carrier's duty entitling levy of charges

anchor.surface_text: The order made by the Tribunal is therefore set aside. The application made under s. 41 in respect of this levy of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck in addition to the carriage is rejected.

outcome.relief_summary: Order of the Tribunal set aside; application under s. 41 rejected

anchor.surface_text: Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-When total charges payable in respect of goods traffic carried by a Railway are increased by the Railway Administration on the basis of terminals fixed by the Central Government in pursuance of s. 32 of the Indian Railways Act, has the Railway Rates Tribunal jurisdiction to investigate the reasonableness of the charge as thus increased ? That is the question raised in this appeal.
The order made by the Tribunal is therefore set aside. The application made under s. 41 in respect of this levy of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck in addition to the carriage is rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the Tribunal  by which we mean the majority of the Tribunal  was wrong in thinking that this was not a case of standardized terminal charges.
The order made by the Tribunal is therefore set aside. The application made under s. 41 in respect of this levy of Rs. 9.6 per 4 wheeler truck in addition to the carriage is rejected.
